title: Diana Ross reveals it's a 'dream come true' as she's confirmed for Glastonbury 2020's 'Legends' slot
text:
Diana Ross has been confirmed to headline the 'Legends' slot on the Pyramid stage at Glastonbury 2020.

The legendary Motown singer, 75, took to Twitter on Thursday after the news was announced, revealing that it was a 'dream come true.'

The 'I'm Coming Out' hitmaker is the first act to be confirmed for the long-running festival, which is set to return for a special 50th anniversary edition next year.

She's coming! Diana Ross is set to add another string to her bow as she's to headline the 'Legends' slot on the Pyramid stage at Glastonbury 2020

Glastonbury 2020 will take place on Worthy Farm in Somerset, South West England, between June 24, 2020 and June 28, 2020.

Sharing her excitement on Twitter, Diana wrote: 'This is a dream come true. To all the fans across the world, this is my tribute to you. I'm coming to Glastonbury, with love.'

The Glastonbury performance marks the first time the Upside Down singer will perform in the UK since her I Love You tour in 2007.

While the festival's organiser Emily Eavis shared her own message about the hit singer taking part.

Star performer: The legendary Motown singer, 75, took to Twitter on Thursday after the news was announced, revealing that it was a 'dream come true'

She wrote: 'I am delighted to say that one of the all-time greats, the wonderful Diana Ross, is coming to Glastonbury to play the Sunday legend slot on the Pyramid next year.'

Diana will follow in the footsteps of a number of big names to have graced the Pyramid stage over the years, including last year's headliner Kylie Minogue, 51.

Kylie's performance came 14 years after she was first asked, but had to pull out due to her devastating cancer diagnosis.

Excited: Sharing her excitement on Twitter, Diana wrote: 'This is a dream come true. To all the fans across the world, this is my tribute to you. I'm coming to Glastonbury, with love'

Her 2019 routine was the most-watch Glastonbury performance of all time on the BBC, with 3.9 million thrilled fans tuning in.

Other music stars to have performed in the Legend's slot include the likes of Dolly Parton, Barry Gibb, Dame Shirley Bassey and Lionel Richie.

Meanwhile, Paul McCarty is rumoured to be joining Diana at the music event next year, after he hinted he could be taking part.

The Beatles legend, 77, said his daughters Stella, 47, and Mary, 50, urged him to do it, said: 'People are saying that it will be good if I did it, so I’m starting to think about whether I can or whether it would be a good thing.

Back again: The Glastonbury performance marks the first time the Upside Down singer will perform in the UK since her I Love You tour in 2007

Thrilled: 'I am delighted to say that one of the all-time greats, the wonderful Diana Ross, is coming to Glastonbury to play the Sunday legend slot on the Pyramid next year'

'My kids are saying, "Dad, we’ve got to talk about Glastonbury", and I think I know what they mean.'

The Hey Jude hitmaker insisted that nothing has been set in stone yet, but it's definitely on the cards.

He added: 'We played there quite a long time ago so maybe it is time to go back. I don’t know. I’d have to put a few things in place.

'It’s starting to become some remote kind of possibility. It’s definitely not fixed yet but people are starting to talk about it.'

Take to the stage: Diana will follow in the footsteps of a number of big names to have graced the Pyramid stage over the years, including last year's headliner Kylie Minogue, 51

Paul's Glasto hint comes after the festival's founder Michael Eavis dropped a huge teaser that the Let it Be hitmaker will be returning to the music extravaganza for its 50th anniversary.

He said: 'Paul's on good form at the moment.'

When asked if he had 'spoken to him' and if he was coming to Worthy Farm, Michael said: 'Hopefully for the 50th, yeah. Don't make a big thing of it though will you?'

Last June, the music icon admitted he would 'probably' headline Glastonbury if he was asked, but he thought his daughters - who he has with late ex-wife Linda - must have been 'drunk' when they announced plans to launch a campaign for their father to top the bill on the iconic Pyramid Stage.

'It's starting to become some remote possibility': Sir Paul McCartney has hinted he's playing Glastonbury next year

He said: 'I think they were drunk weren't they? They have said to me actually, "Dad you've got to do it, you've got to do it".

'I haven't really spoken to anyone about it. It's a little while since we did it. And we did enjoy doing it. The conversation hasn't gone any further.'

Tickets for next year's Glastonbury reportedly sold out in 34 seconds on Sunday, with 2.4 million fans trying to bag the 135,000 tickets that were up for grabs.
